questions.text: A 51-year-old bomb blast victim is brought to the casualty with life-threatening injuries. There was a lot of chaos and no one was available to sign consent for emergency surgery. Despite surgery the patient died. The doctor is not responsible under which doctrine? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Doctrine of anticipation

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Doctrine of anticipation," which permits medical interventions without prior consent in emergencies where delays could result in harm or death to the patient. This doctrine is crucial in understanding the legal protections afforded to doctors making critical decisions under duress and with the intent to save lives.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child is brought to the emergency department by his parents after accidentally ingesting several iron tablets. Based on the progression of iron toxicity, arrange the symptoms in the correct order as they typically appear during the condition?

options.label: A
options.text: Hepatotoxicity, GI irritation, metabolic acidosis, bowel obstruction

options.label: B
options.text: GI irritation, latent phase, shock and metabolic acidosis, hepatic necrosis

options.label: C
options.text: Bowel obstruction, GI irritation, shock, recovery from GI symptoms

options.label: D
options.text: Latent phase, metabolic acidosis, GI irritation, hepatotoxicity

questions.correct_answer: B. GI irritation, latent phase, shock and metabolic acidosis, hepatic necrosis
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Iron toxicity progresses through several distinct stages, starting with initial gastrointestinal (GI) irritation that occurs within 30 minutes to 6 hours of ingestion. This stage is marked by symptoms like vomiting, abdominal pain, and diarrhea. Following this, the latent phase (Stage II) occurs between 6 to 24 hours, during which GI symptoms may temporarily subside, misleading caregivers into thinking the patient is recovering. However, this is followed by Stage III, which involves shock and metabolic acidosis, occurring between 6 to 72 hours, characterized by severe systemic symptoms such as dehydration, shock, and lactic acidosis. Stage IV, occurring between 12 to 96 hours, involves hepatotoxicity and hepatic necrosis, which can lead to liver failure. Finally, Stage V involves GI mucosal healing leading to scarring and bowel obstruction, which can occur weeks later.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Hepatotoxicity, GI irritation, metabolic acidosis, bowel obstruction: This order is incorrect as it suggests hepatotoxicity precedes GI irritation, which does not align with the progression of iron toxicity stages.
  • • A. Hepatotoxicity, GI irritation, metabolic acidosis, bowel obstruction:
  • • C. Bowel obstruction, GI irritation, shock, recovery from GI symptoms: This sequence incorrectly places bowel obstruction as the initial event, whereas it occurs much later in the toxicity progression, after the acute systemic effects.
  • • C. Bowel obstruction, GI irritation, shock, recovery from GI symptoms:
  • • D. Latent p
  • • D. Latent p
  • • hase, metabolic acidosis, GI irritation, hepatotoxicity: This order is incorrect because GI irritation is the first stage, not preceded by the latent phase or metabolic acidosis.
  • • hase, metabolic acidosis, GI irritation, hepatotoxicity:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Iron toxicity progresses through five stages: initial GI irritation, a deceptive latent phase, severe systemic effects including shock and metabolic acidosis, hepatic necrosis, and finally, late-onset bowel obstruction due to scarring. Recognizing the sequence of these stages is crucial for timely intervention and management in cases of acute iron overdose.

questions.text: A doctor mistakenly uses the same needle on two patients, one of whom is HIV-positive. The second patient subsequently tests positive for HIV. Under which section of the Indian Penal Code (IPC) is the doctor liable for this act of negligence? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Section 269 of the IPC specifically addresses negligent acts that are likely to spread infection or disease dangerous to life. In this scenario, the doctor's reuse of a contaminated needle is a clear act of negligence that directly led to the transmission of HIV, a life-threatening disease, to the second patient.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Section 166B: This section pertains to punishment for a public servant disobeying a direction of the law with intent to cause injury to any person. While the doctor's action may be considered a violation of medical protocols, it doesn't directly fall under this section. Section 202: This section addresses the intentional omission to give information of an offense by a person legally bound to inform. It's not relevant in this case where the act was negligent, not intentional. Section 203: Similar to Section 202, this section deals with giving false information regarding an offense, which is not applicable to this situation.
  • • Section 166B: This section pertains to punishment for a public servant disobeying a direction of the law with intent to cause injury to any person. While the doctor's action may be considered a violation of medical protocols, it doesn't directly fall under this section.
  • • Section 166B:
  • • Section 202: This section addresses the intentional omission to give information of an offense by a person legally bound to inform. It's not relevant in this case where the act was negligent, not intentional.
  • • Section 202:
  • • Section 203: Similar to Section 202, this section deals with giving false information regarding an offense, which is not applicable to this situation.
  • • Section 203:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Section 269 of the IPC is crucial in addressing cases of medical negligence where a healthcare provider's actions lead to the spread of infectious diseases. It highlights the importance of adhering to infection control practices to prevent the transmission of communicable diseases.

  • ➤ ABCDE of trauma care:

  • ➤ Adjuncts to the primary survey are-

When required, all these x rays must also be done in pregnant women.

  • ➤ ECG, pulse oximetry, ventilatory rate, capnography, ABG analysis

  • ➤ Other more specialized forms of imaging, such as ultrasound, computerized tomography, angiography, and diagnostic peritoneal lavage, should be considered after the secondary survey and only in a patient stable after initial resuscitation.

questions.text: All of the following take part in the formation of the wrist joint, except: ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Distal end of ulna

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The distal end of the ulna does not directly participate in the wrist joint. Instead, it articulates with the triangular fibrocartilage complex (TFCC). The TFCC acts as a cushion and allows for the smooth rotation of the radius over the ulna during forearm pronation and supination. Due to this articulation with the TFCC and not with the carpal bones, the distal end of the ulna does not form the wrist joint. .
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Scaphoid : The scaphoid is one of the eight carpal bones in the wrist and is situated on the radial side of the carpus. It articulates proximally with the radius and participates in the formation of the wrist joint.
  • • Option A.
  • • Scaphoid
  • • Option B . Triquetrum : The triquetrum is another one of the carpal bones. It is located on the ulnar side of the carpus. Like the scaphoid, the triquetrum also articulates with the distal end of the radius, contributing to the wrist joint's structure.
  • • Option B
  • • Triquetrum
  • • Option C . Distal end of radius : The wrist joint is primarily formed by the articulation between the distal end of the radius and the proximal row of carpal bones, specifically the scaphoid, lunate, and triquetrum. Thus, the distal end of the radius plays a crucial role in the formation and function of the wrist joint.
  • • Option C
  • • Distal end of radius

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The radiocarpal joint, also known as the wrist joint, is a synovial, biaxial, and ellipsoid joint created by the articulation of:
  • ➤ Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum
  • ➤ Triangular fibrocartilage articular disc
  • ➤ The scaphoids, lunates, and triquetrum
  • ➤ Just the scaphoid and lunate are in contact with the radius and articular disc when the wrist is in its neutral position; the triquetrum does not come into contact with the disc until the wrist joint is fully adducted.

questions.text: What is the mechanism of action of cyclosporine? ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Inhibition of calcineurin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Cyclosporine exerts its immunosuppressive effects by inhibiting calcineurin, thereby preventing the activation of T cells and reducing the production of cytokines such as IL-2. This mechanism is crucial for its role in preventing graft rejection and managing autoimmune diseases.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department after being found unconscious at home. On examination, she is drowsy with a pulse rate of 130/min and a respiratory rate of 28/min. Arterial blood gas (ABG) analysis reveals severe metabolic acidosis with a pH of 7.15. Urine analysis shows the presence of calcium oxalate crystals. Based on these findings, what is the most likely cause of her poisoning?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by severe metabolic acidosis, altered mental status, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which are key diagnostic findings. Ethylene glycol, commonly found in antifreeze, is metabolized into toxic metabolites, including glycolic acid and oxalic acid, which contribute to metabolic acidosis and can lead to renal failure. The deposition of calcium oxalate crystals in the kidneys further impairs renal function and is a hallmark of ethylene glycol toxicity. Symptoms often include drowsiness, tachycardia, and rapid breathing due to the acidosis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Methanol: Methanol poisoning also causes metabolic acidosis and visual disturbances but does not typically result in calcium oxalate crystal formation in the urine. Methanol is primarily metabolized into formic acid, leading to ocular toxicity and acidosis without the renal crystal deposition seen in ethylene glycol poisoning.
  • • A. Methanol:
  • • B. Isopropyl alcohol: Isopropyl alcohol ingestion leads to central nervous system depression and the presence of acetone in the blood, causing fruity breath odor. It does not cause metabolic acidosis or the formation of calcium oxalate crystals, distinguishing it from ethylene glycol poisoning.
  • • B. Isopropyl alcohol:
  • • D. Carbon monoxide: Carbon monoxide poisoning presents with symptoms such as headache, confusion, and cherry-red skin but does not cause metabolic acidosis or calcium oxalate crystals in the urine. It primarily impairs oxygen delivery by binding to hemoglobin, resulting in hypoxia rather than renal effects.
  • • D. Carbon monoxide:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethylene glycol poisoning is characterized by severe metabolic acidosis, altered mental status, and the presence of calcium oxalate crystals in the urine, which is pathognomonic for this type of poisoning. Early recognition and treatment are crucial to prevent severe renal impairment and other systemic complications associated with ethylene glycol toxicity.

questions.text: A pregnant lady of 49 kg is in her first trimester. What are her additional calorie requirements in this trimester? (INICET NOV 2017)

  • • 340 Kcal in 2nd trimester
  • • 452 Kcal in 3rd trimester

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ There are no additional calorie requirements in the first trimester of pregnancy.

questions.text: Which of the following findings is NOT suggestive of child abuse? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Wormian bones are extra bone pieces within the skull sutures. While they can be a normal variant, they are also associated with certain genetic conditions like osteogenesis imperfecta (brittle bone disease). They are not typically indicative of child abuse.
  • • The other options are highly suggestive of child abuse:
  • • The other options are highly suggestive of child abuse:
  • • Microfractures in the sub-epiphyseal region: These tiny fractures near the growth plate are often caused by forceful twisting or shaking of a child's limb. Corner fractures: Also known as bucket-handle fractures, these fractures occur at the metaphysis (the growing part of a long bone) and are highly specific for child abuse, often resulting from violent shaking or pulling. Bucket handle fractures of metaphyses: This is another term for corner fractures, emphasizing their characteristic appearance on X-rays.
  • • Microfractures in the sub-epiphyseal region: These tiny fractures near the growth plate are often caused by forceful twisting or shaking of a child's limb.
  • • Microfractures in the sub-epiphyseal region:
  • • Corner fractures: Also known as bucket-handle fractures, these fractures occur at the metaphysis (the growing part of a long bone) and are highly specific for child abuse, often resulting from violent shaking or pulling.
  • • Corner fractures:
  • • Bucket handle fractures of metaphyses: This is another term for corner fractures, emphasizing their characteristic appearance on X-rays.
  • • Bucket handle fractures of metaphyses:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ While several skeletal injuries are strong indicators of child abuse, Wormian bones are not. They are more commonly associated with genetic conditions like osteogenesis imperfecta.

questions.text: A and B in the graph below represent which of the following ions, in terms of permeability for action potential generation: (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: A is Na+, B is K+

options.label: B
options.text: A is Na+, B is Ca2+

options.label: C
options.text: A is K+, B is Ca2+

options.label: D
options.text: A is Ca2+, B is K+

questions.correct_answer: A. A is Na+, B is K+
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) A is Na+, B is K+

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ During an action potential, the initial rapid depolarization is due to an increase in Na+ permeability (represented by A), followed by repolarization due to an increase in K+ permeability (represented by B).

questions.text: A pediatrician is reviewing various constitutional provisions to understand which ones directly address the welfare and protection of children. During this review, the pediatrician identifies one article that primarily deals with workers' rights and maternity relief rather than focusing on children's care. Which of the following constitutional articles is not directly related to pediatric care?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Article 42 of the constitution is concerned with securing just and humane conditions of work and maternity relief, focusing on the welfare of workers, especially women, by ensuring proper working conditions and maternity benefits. Although it indirectly benefits children through maternity support, it does not specifically address pediatric care or child welfare. Articles like 21A, 45, and 47 focus on child-specific needs, such as education, nutrition, and overall welfare, which are more directly related to pediatric care.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Article 45: Article 45 directs the state to provide early childhood care and education for all children until they complete the age of six years. It specifically addresses the needs of young children and directly relates to pediatric care and development.
  • • A. Article 45:
  • • B. Article 47: Article 47 imposes a duty on the state to raise the level of nutrition, standard of living, and public health, including that of children. It focuses on the overall health and well-being of the population, including pediatric concerns.
  • • B. Article 47:
  • • D. Article 21A: Article 21A mandates the right to free and compulsory education for children aged 6 to 14 years, directly addressing the educational rights of children, making it directly relevant to their welfare and development.
  • • D. Article 21A:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Article 42 is primarily focused on working conditions and maternity relief and does not specifically address pediatric care, unlike Articles 21A, 45, and 47, which are directly aimed at the welfare, education, and health of children. Understanding the scope of these constitutional articles helps in identifying which provisions are designed to protect and promote child health and welfare.

questions.text: After a fall from a height, a 10-year-old child presented to the emergency department with complaints of abdominal pain. Upon examination, the child's vital signs were stable, but tenderness was noted in the left lumbar region. What would be the best investigation of choice? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice. This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.
  • ➤ In cases of suspected blunt renal trauma, particularly in a hemodynamically stable patient, a contrast-enhanced CT scan is the investigation of choice.
  • ➤ This allows for detailed imaging of the abdomen to accurately diagnose and assess the extent of the injury.

questions.text: Which of the following sensory receptors are responsible for tactile discrimination? ( INICET May 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Meissner's corpuscle

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meissner's corpuscles are specialized for discriminative touch, enabling precise location and detection of fine tactile stimuli. They are most abundant in areas where tactile acuity is high, such as the fingertips and lips

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR. ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin. Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester. Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased. Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy. Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.
  • • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • • Fibrinogen Levels:
  • • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • • ESR:
  • • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • • Platelet Count:
  • • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • • Coagulation Factors:
  • • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • • Clotting Time:
  • • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.
  • • Anti-Thrombin III:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.
  • • Option A. Albumin:
  • • Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.
  • • Option B. Platelet:
  • • Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg59
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg59

questions.text: A 6-month-old infant is brought to the pediatric clinic for a routine check-up. The physician notes normal growth and development for age. To assess bone age and growth plate maturation, an X-ray of the wrist is performed. The radiograph shows the presence of a carpal bone that has already started ossifying. Given the age of the infant, which carpal bone is the most likely to have appeared first on the X-ray?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The capitate is the first carpal bone to undergo ossification, typically appearing around 2 months of age. This bone, along with the hamate, which also begins to ossify around the same time, is among the earliest of the carpal bones visible on radiographs in infants. The ossification of the capitate is used as a marker for bone age in early infancy. The appearance of carpal bones follows a predictable sequence, starting with the capitate and hamate, followed by other bones like the triquetral, lunate, and so forth, with the pisiform being the last to ossify.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • A. Trapezium: The trapezium usually begins ossification around 6 years of age, making it unlikely to be seen on an X-ray of an infant. It appears much later in the sequence of carpal bone development.
  • • A. Trapezium:
  • • B. Hamate: The hamate also begins ossification early, at around 2 months of age, but it is still the second carpal bone to appear after the capitate, not the first.
  • • B. Hamate:
  • • C. Triquetrum: The triquetrum typically ossifies around 3 years of age, significantly later than the capitate and hamate. It is not visible on X-rays of infants, as its ossification occurs during early childhood.
  • • C. Triquetrum:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The capitate is the first carpal bone to ossify, typically appearing around 2 months of age, followed closely by the hamate. Recognition of the ossification sequence of carpal bones is crucial for assessing bone age and developmental milestones in pediatric patients

questions.text: Which of the following structures does the cell pointed red arrow inhibit?(AIIMS NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Deep nuclei of cerebellum

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image shows a histopathological section of the cerebellum. The cells marked with the arrow are Purkinje cells and they inhibit deep nuclei of the cerebellum.
  • • Within the white matter, there are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.
  • • Detailed Overview of Cerebellar Architecture:
  • • Detailed Overview of Cerebellar Architecture:
  • • 1. Three Layers of the Cerebellar Cortex :
  • • 1. Three Layers of the Cerebellar Cortex
  • • Molecular Layer : This is the outermost layer and contains stellate and basket cells. The dendrites of Purkinje cells also extend into this layer. The axons of granule cells, called parallel fibers, run horizontally in this layer. Purkinje Cell Layer : This layer contains the large, flask-shaped Purkinje cells, which are the principal neurons of the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells have a single axon that travels to the deep cerebellar nuclei and extensive dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer. They are inhibitory neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter. Granule Cell Layer : The innermost layer contains numerous small granule cells, along with Golgi cells. Granule cells are excitatory neurons that use glutamate as their neurotransmitter. Their axons ascend into the molecular layer where they bifurcate and run as parallel fibers, synapsing with Purkinje cell dendrites.
  • • Molecular Layer : This is the outermost layer and contains stellate and basket cells. The dendrites of Purkinje cells also extend into this layer. The axons of granule cells, called parallel fibers, run horizontally in this layer.
  • • Molecular Layer
  • • Purkinje Cell Layer : This layer contains the large, flask-shaped Purkinje cells, which are the principal neurons of the cerebellar cortex. Purkinje cells have a single axon that travels to the deep cerebellar nuclei and extensive dendritic trees that extend into the molecular layer. They are inhibitory neurons that use GABA as their neurotransmitter.
  • • Purkinje Cell Layer
  • • Granule Cell Layer : The innermost layer contains numerous small granule cells, along with Golgi cells. Granule cells are excitatory neurons that use glutamate as their neurotransmitter. Their axons ascend into the molecular layer where they bifurcate and run as parallel fibers, synapsing with Purkinje cell dendrites.
  • • Granule Cell Layer
  • • 2. White Matter : Beneath the cerebellar cortex is the cerebellar white matter, which consists of myelinated axons. These axons form the afferent and efferent connections of the cerebellum.
  • • 2. White Matter
  • • 3. Deep Cerebellar Nuclei : Within the white matter are four pairs of deep cerebellar nuclei: the fastigial, globose, emboliform (these last two are collectively called the interposed nuclei), and the dentate nuclei. These nuclei receive inhibitory input from Purkinje cells and excitatory input from cerebellar afferents and provide the primary output from the cerebellum to other brain regions.
  • • 3. Deep Cerebellar Nuclei
  • • 4. Afferent and Efferent Fibers : The cerebellum receives input (afferent fibers) mainly from the spinal cord, brainstem, and cerebral cortex and sends output (efferent fibers) to the deep cerebellar nuclei and then out to various parts of the brain, primarily the vestibular nuclei and the thalamus.
  • • 4. Afferent and Efferent Fibers
  • • 5. Bergmann Glia : These are specialized astrocytes found in the cerebellum. They have long processes that extend through the Purkinje cell layer into the molecular layer, providing support for neurons and playing a role in neurotransmission.
  • • 5. Bergmann Glia
  • • 6. Foliation : Grossly, the cerebellum exhibits a series of folia (folds) which are a result of the convolution of the cerebellar cortex.
  • • 6. Foliation
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A: Vestibular nuclei and Option C: Basal ganglia are not directly influenced by Purkinje cells.
  • • Option A: Vestibular nuclei
  • • Option C: Basal ganglia
  • • Option B: Anterior horn of spinal is involved in motor neuron activity, unrelated to Purkinje cell output.
  • • Option B: Anterior horn of spinal

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Purkinje cells in the cerebellum play a vital inhibitory role on the deep cerebellar nuclei, crucial for coordinating and refining motor movements and cognitive processing related to movement.

questions.text: A 50-year-old woman presents with abnormal uterine bleeding for two months. What is the next line of management? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Endometrial sampling

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The next line of management in a 50-year-old woman with abnormal uterine bleeding (AUB) is an endometrial biopsy. This is crucial to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy, especially in a peri-menopausal woman.
  • • Indications for Endometrial Sampling:
  • • Indications for Endometrial Sampling:
  • • Peri-menopausal women with AUB. Hyperestrogenic states like obesity or tamoxifen treatment with thickened endometrium on transvaginal sonography (TVS). Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding. Transvaginal ultrasound findings of endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.
  • • Peri-menopausal women with AUB.
  • • Hyperestrogenic states like obesity or tamoxifen treatment with thickened endometrium on transvaginal sonography (TVS).
  • • Women with failed medical management and persistent bleeding.
  • • Transvaginal ultrasound findings of endometrial thickness >12 mm in premenopausal women and >4 mm in postmenopausal women.
  • • Methods of Endometrial Sampling:
  • • Methods of Endometrial Sampling:
  • • Curettage Aspiration biopsy using Pipelle or Vibra aspirator
  • • Curettage
  • • Aspiration biopsy using Pipelle or Vibra aspirator
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. LNG-IUCD: The Levonorgestrel intrauterine device (LNG-IUCD) is a treatment option but should be considered after ruling out malignancy.
  • • Option A. LNG-IUCD:
  • • Option B. POP for 3 months: Progestin-only pills (POP) can be used to manage AUB, but endometrial sampling should be done first to rule out malignancy.
  • • Option B. POP for 3 months:
  • • Option C. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy is a definitive treatment but is considered after other management options and ruling out malignancy.
  • • Option C. Hysterectomy:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In peri-menopausal women presenting with abnormal uterine bleeding, the first step is to perform endometrial sampling to rule out endometrial hyperplasia or malignancy before considering other treatment modalities.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg184
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition Pg184
